body: Linda A. is one of the lucky ones. She survived the subway crash at Union Square on Aug. 28 that killed five people, including a close friend of hers. But she survived to be haunted by the vivid memories of "the smoke and the screams," and the image of the mangled body of her friend, Richard Limehouse. She survived to ask herself, "Why did I live?"
title: After a Crash, Help From Neediest

body: Public School 139 in Flatbush is six blocks from a once-boycotted Korean grocery store and a comfortable hike from two neighborhoods synonymous with ethnic tension, Crown Heights and Bensonhurst. But yesterday, black, Hispanic, Asian and white third graders, radiant in their white assembly-day shirts and blouses, thronged together to sing songs of
title: At P.S. 139, a Hanuk-Chris-Kwanz-Etc. Pageant

body: When he came to America from his native South Korea nine years ago, Won So's English was so poor that he could not summon the words or the courage to ask his third-grade teacher for permission to go to the bathroom. "I would always run to my father's store after school to use the toilet," said Mr. So, now a loquacious 18-year-old senior at
title: From Diffident Youth to Student Advocate

body: Every day, as he cruises Manhattan in his taxicab, Samuel Cohen sees the toll homelessness exacts on the indigent, addicted and infirm. He solemnly nods and says the city should help those souls find their way into a home. But standing in his driveway and glancing down the block at an empty lot where the city has proposed building a shelter for
title: Charity Comes Too Close to Home

A replica of a Viking ship sailed by Leif Ericsson nearly 1,000 years ago will be docked at the seaport through Wednesday. Part of "Finland Revisited -- 1,000 Years of
title: OFFBEAT

body: The Canarsie real-estate office that had been firebombed twice this summer in bias attacks was vandalized again early yesterday, bringing back to the surface the racial tensions that had flared after the earlier attacks. Rumors swept through the streets of the Brooklyn neighborhood today, accompanied by a small group of reporters and camera crews.
title: Realty Building In Canarsie Hit By Firecrackers

body: A Brooklyn real estate office, which had sold homes to black and Hispanic families in the mostly white section of Canarsie, was firebombed early this morning for the third time in three months, the police said. The latest incident occurred shortly after midnight at the Fillmore Real Estate agency at 9301 Flatlands Avenue, which has been under a
title: Canarsie Real Estate Office Is Firebombed Again

title: Candidates Crowd the Field in Primary for Council

body: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is more often identified with giant undertakings than neighborhood-sized projects. But under its 10-month-old Urban and Community Development Program, $5 million is to be awarded to "highly distressed areas" for storefront improvements, feasibility studies and project planning. Among the latest
title: POSTINGS: U.D.C. in the Neighborhoods; Aid Sprinkles

body: It had been a good collar. Two police officers on patrol in Brooklyn had stopped a car for a traffic infraction and discovered that they had caught three suspects in a burglary that had occurred only minutes before. But like a story line on "Hill Street Blues," where events do not always happen as planned, things started to go awry rather quickly.
title: A Sharp Arrest, Some Gunshots, Then an Escape

body: Children's Art Show Paramount Gallery Long Island University 1 University Plaza DeKalb and Flatbush Avenues Downtown Brooklyn (718) 783-3077 Recommended ages: 7 and up Through Sept. 13 This exhibition of artwork by Brooklyn junior and senior high school students reflects the borough's diversity. Working in conjunction with the Brooklyn Arts
title: For Children

body: JUAN GUERRERO grows tomatillos on a scrap of land that used to be a chop shop for stolen cars in the South Bronx. It's his little piece of Mexico. "He says you cut them up with hot pepper for salsa," said Jose Garcia, who grew up in Puerto Rico. Mr. Guerrero left of Puebla, Mexico, four years ago, but he speaks little English, so Mr. Garcia was
title: In a Mix of Cultures, An Olio of Plantings

body: A day after holding a watermelon aloft to taunt black protesters in Canarsie, a 20-year-old white man was charged with the firebombing that had made his neighborhood the latest focus for New York City's racial tensions, the police said. Tips from neighbors led to the arrest of the man, Brian Fining, in the July 27 firebombing of a real-estate
title: Suspect Seized In Bias Arson In Canarsie

body: More than 300 chanting, placard-waving black demonstrators led by the Rev. Al Sharpton staged a tense protest march through Brooklyn's racially troubled, predominantly white Canarsie section yesterday and were met with taunts, jeers and racial insults but no violence. An escort of 400 riot-equipped police officers on foot and motorcycle encircled
title: Taunts and Outrage Greet Protest March in Canarsie

body: A New York City police officer was suspended yesterday after being indicted on charges of hampering a murder investigation and tampering with a witness, the police said. According to the police account, the indicted officer, Victor Little, 25 years old, was out with friends on Dec. 30, 1990, when a dispute erupted between his friends and Cleveland
title: Police Officer Is Suspended After Tampering Indictment

body: A 24-year-old black woman has been arrested in Brooklyn in what the police said was a bias incident involving an assault on a 32-year-old white woman over their children's use of a sprinkler in a Canarsie park. The incident, which was among 11 bias-related incidents in Canarsie in recent months, occurred at 1:30 P.M. on July 19 in a park at Remson
title: Black Woman Held in Attack Linked to Bias

body: Madgaline Michael's childhood was spent in Jefferson, S.C., in the days before the clamor for racial equality swept through the South. As a black person of mature years, she is no neophyte to racism. Nor, as a resident of New York City for 32 years, is she naive about crime. But Ms. Michael was stunned last week, when her son became one of the
title: Canarsie's Long-Held Racial Anxieties Resurface

body: Two white teen-agers have told the police that they were beaten with sticks by a group of seven or eight black men early yesterday on East 95th Street near Flatlands Avenue in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn. The assault was the 10th bias-related attack or threat reported in the last month in the predominantly white, middle-class community, the
title: Another Bias Crime in Canarsie: 2 Whites Tell Police of Attack

body: A black man has told the police that he was taunted and slashed by four white teen-agers early yesterday morning while playing with his 2-year-old daughter in a Canarsie playground. The police have classified the case as bias-related. It comes after a series of racially motivated attacks and threats last month in the southeastern Brooklyn
title: Black Man Tells Police Of Attack by 4 Whites

body: PAINFULLY early one morning a few years ago, a pack of tourists knocked at the door of Anthony and Maryann Cucchiara's 18th-century Dutch farmhouse in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn. Not expecting a crowd, Mrs. Cucchiara answered the door dressed in a flannel nightgown. "They were a group of senior citizens who thought this was a museum," she
title: Who Lives There, Anyway? Faces Behind the Walls: Flatlands; A Tidy Farmhouse Grows in Brooklyn

body: The police searched unsuccessfully yesterday for a suspect in the firebombings of a real-estate company that sold homes to black families in Canarsie. But both black and white residents of the Brooklyn neighborhood said that behind the crimes lay tensions stemming from an influx of newcomers into a traditionally white area. The number of minority
title: Neighbors Assess Tensions That Led to Firebombings

body: A real-estate office in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn known for selling homes in the mostly white neighborhood to blacks was firebombed early yesterday for the second time in two weeks. The police called it a bias crime. The agency, Fillmore Real Estate, at 9301 Flatlands Avenue, was also bombed on July 16, two days after an unidentified caller
title: Real-Estate Agency Firebombed Again

title: Residential Resales

body: A Brooklyn real-estate agency damaged by a fire on Tuesday had been under a court order to show homes to black and Hispanic customers, and the New York City Commission on Human Rights suggested yesterday that the company had been attacked because it was complying with the order. The police have described the early-morning blaze at the Fillmore Real
title: Realty Agency in Fire Subject to Bias Order

body: A Brooklyn real-estate agency was set afire early yesterday morning, two days after workers there reported receiving threatening calls about selling property to minorities in a predominantly white neighborhood, the police said. The fire, which the police have deemed a bias incident, began around 4 A.M. on the roof of the Fillmore Real Estate agency
title: Realty Concern Set Afire in Case Linked to Bias

body: Here is a sampling of events planned around New York City for the Fourth of July weekend: Today ANNUAL AIR SHOW, Coney Island, Brooklyn. The United States Army's eight-member Green Beret parachute team is to land on the beach today through Sunday at 12:30 P.M. Also taking part in the show tomorrow and on Sunday will be an Air Force F-16 plane,
title: The Fourth, Continued

body: A pregnant woman was killed and nine other women were injured yesterday when a drunken driver drove onto a sidewalk in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn during the morning rush hour, the police said. In just seconds in front of South Shore High School on Ralph Avenue, the driver's car hit two people on the sidewalk, then careered through a bus
title: Pregnant Woman Hit and Killed By Car on a Brooklyn Sidewalk

body: A 60-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed last night when a purse snatcher grabbed her from a passing car and dragged her at least 30 feet, witnesses told the police. The attack, which occurred at 5:40 P.M., was the third mugging in two weeks in the quiet, residential Flatlands community of single-family homes just north of Marine Park, said shocked
title: Mugger in Car Drags Woman To Her Death

body: International A3-9 The final pillar of statutory apartheid was scrapped by the South African Parliament 41 years after it was enacted. The law laid the legal foundation of apartheid by classifying all South Africans by race. Page A1 A lifting of the economic sanctions against South Africa will be sought by the Bush Administration in reaction to the
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: A police lieutenant's teen-age son was shot to death Friday night as an act of retaliation arising from his attempt to help a young woman who had been beaten earlier in the day, the police said yesterday. Investigators originally said the shooting of Gavin Harris, 14 years old, as he rode his bike in his Flatlands neighborhood was apparently a case
title: Killing of Brooklyn Boy Called Act of Retaliation

body: In what was apparently a case of mistaken identity, the 14-year-old son of a Brooklyn police lieutenant was shot in the back and killed while riding his bicycle early Friday evening, the police said yesterday. Sgt. James McCoy of the 63d Precinct detective squad said that several young men accosted the victim, Gavin Harris, shorly before he was
title: Son of Police Lieutenant Is Killed After Apparent Mistake of Identity

body: One woman was shot and killed and two girls, 11 and 13 years old, and a boy, 14, were shot and wounded in three incidents yesterday in Brooklyn. All were bystanders, the police said. The woman, Maribel Nieves, 34, of 374 Sumpter Street, was shot in the head and killed and the 14-year-old boy was wounded in the right leg as they walked near two men
title: Brooklyn Shootings Kill One Bystander; 3 Others Wounded

body: A 51-year-old man believed to be connected to organized crime was found shot to death last night in the lobby of his apartment building in Brooklyn, the police said. The man, Alfred Visconti, of 2020 East 41st Street in the Flatlands section, had been shot several times, a police spokesman, Officer Fred Weiner, said. The body was found by building
title: Man Found Slain in Brooklyn

body: AT about the same time that he discovered the island that bears his name, the Dutch navigator Adrian Block mapped the islands and inlets of what is today the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn. That was in 1614, 22 years before the Canarsee Indians, who lived there, sold their land (and water) to Dutch settlers, setting the stage for development. It
title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Mill Basin

body: On Monday night, a Brooklyn woman was bound and repeatedly raped by two men in her home. On Thursday, the detectives arrested a 19-year-old man and charged him in the attack. The victim was able to provide only a sketchy description of her attackers. It is the kind of crime that investigators expect to be able to solve only after weeks of
title: New Fingerprint Computers Speed Rape Suspect's Arrest

body: A Brooklyn grand jury yesterday voted not to indict an off-duty rookie police officer who shot a 23-year-old man three times in the back while the man was stealing the officer's car, the authorities said. The 23-member panel issued its decision, called a "no true bill," after a three-week investigation that included testimony from 11 witnesses and
title: Officer Cleared in Killing of Auto Thief

body: A rookie police officer was charged with murder yesterday afternoon in the fatal shooting of a man trying to steal his car Thursday morning as the officer was getting ready to go to work, the police said. The officer, Robert W. Smith, told investigators that he had surprised the man, Raphael Martinez, inside his car in front of his Brooklyn house,
title: Officer Who Shot Car-Theft Suspect Faces Murder Charge

body: A suspect with a long conviction record -- including several robberies on subways -- was charged with murder yesterday in the death of a purse-snatching victim who was dragged by a train along a subway platform Tuesday morning while chasing her attacker. The suspect, Brian Lawrence, 30 years old, of Irvington, N.J., admitted in written and
title: Purse-Snatching Suspect Is Charged With Murder

body: Daniel M. C. Hopping, an architect who specialized in restorations and who supervised the installation of 14 historic American rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died on Dec. 26 at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 85 years old and lived in Bronxville. He died after a heart attack, said Mary Huber, Bronxville's village historian
title: Daniel M.C. Hopping
